revision.comment: Alter: template type, title. Add: work, journal. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]]; [[Category:Galaxies]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox Website | name = Galaxy Zoo | logo = File:Galaxyzoo.jpg | caption = The [[Zooniverse]] Galaxy Zoo logo | url = {{URL|http://www.galaxyzoo.org}} | commercial = No | type = Volunteer Scientific Project | language = English, French, Spanish, German, Polish, Czech, Chinese | registration = Yes | owner = The Citizen Science Alliance | author = Galaxy Zoo Team | launch date = 11 July 2007 | current status = Ongoing }}
'''Galaxy Zoo''' is a [[crowdsource]]d [[astronomy]] project which invites people to assist in the [[galaxy morphological classification|morphological classification]] of large numbers of [[galaxy|galaxies]]. It is an example of [[citizen science]] as it enlists the help of members of the public to help in scientific research.<ref name="GZ_Motivations">{{Cite journal |last=Raddick |first=M. Jordan |last2=Bracey |first2=Georgia |last3=Gay |first3=Pamela L. |last4=Lintott |first4=C. J. |author-link4=Chris Lintott |last5=Murray |first5=Phil |last6=Schawinski |first6=Kevin |author-link6=Kevin Schawinski |last7=Szalay |first7=Alexander S. |author-link7=Alex Szalay |last8=Vandenberg |first8=Jan |date=December 2010 |orig-year=16 Sep 2009 |title=Galaxy Zoo:Exploring the motivations of citizen science volunteers |journal=[[American Astronomical Society|Astronomy Education Review]] |volume=9 |issue=1 |page=010103 |arxiv=0909.2925 |bibcode=2010AEdRv...9a0103R |doi=10.3847/AER2009036}}</ref><ref name=GZ_Motivations2>{{ cite paper| title=Galaxy Zoo: Motivations of Citizen Scientists|first1=M. Jordan |last1=Raddick |first2=Georgia |last2=Bracey |first3=Pamela L. |last3=Gay |first4=Chris J. |last4=Lintott |authorlink4=Chris Lintott|first5=Carie |last5=Cardamone |first6=Phil |last6=Murray |first7=Kevin |last7=Schawinski |author-link7=Kevin Schawinski|first8=Alexander S. |last8=Szalay |author-link8=Alex Szalay|first9=Jan |last9=Vandenberg | date=27 Mar 2013| arxiv=1303.6886v1 }}</ref>
There have been 15 versions as of July 2017, many of which are outlined in this article.<ref name=BBC_GZ10/> Galaxy Zoo is part of the [[Zooniverse (citizen science project)|Zooniverse]], a group of citizen science projects. An outcome of the project is to better determine the different aspects of objects and to separate them into classifications.
== Origins ==
[[File:apache-0110.JPG|left|thumb| ARCSAT and [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey|SDSS]] telescope buildings at the [[Apache Point Observatory]]]] A key factor leading to the creation of the project was the problem of what has been referred to as [[data deluge]], where research produces vast sets of information to the extent that research teams are not able to analyse and process much of it.<ref name=eurdeluge>{{cite news|title=Experts want EU to tackle scientific data deluge|url=http://www.euractiv.com/innovation-enterprise/experts-want-eu-tackle-scientifi-news-498556|publisher=EurActiv.com|accessdate=18 July 2014|date=7 October 2010}}</ref><ref name="dailydeluge">{{Cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/04/110422131123.htm |title=Supercomputers: 'Data Deluge' Is Changing, Expanding Supercomputer-Based Research |last=Zverina |first=Jan |date=24 April 2011 |publisher=[[Science Daily]] |access-date=25 August 2011}}</ref><ref name="time">{{Cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1975296,00.html |title=How to Classify a Million Galaxies in Three Weeks |journal=Time |last=Pinkowski |first=Jennifer |date=28 March 2010 |access-date=21 July 2011}}</ref> [[Kevin Schawinski]], previously an astrophysicist at [[Oxford University]] and co-founder of Galaxy Zoo, described the problem that led to Galaxy Zoo's creation when he was set the task of classifying the morphology of more than 900,000 galaxies by eye that had been imaged by the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]] at the [[Apache Point Observatory]] in [[New Mexico]], [[United States|USA]]. "I classified 50,000 galaxies myself in a week, it was mind-numbing."<ref name="BBC">{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/6289474.stm |title=Scientists seek galaxy hunt help |last=McGourty |first=Christine |date=11 July 2007 |access-date=12 July 2007 |publisher=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> [[Chris Lintott]], also a co-founder of the project, stated: "In many parts of science, we're not constrained by what data we can get, we're constrained by what we can do with the data we have. Citizen science is a very powerful way of solving that problem."<ref name="time"/>
The Galaxy Zoo concept was inspired by others such as [[Stardust@home]], where the public was asked by [[NASA]] to search images obtained from a mission to a [[comet]] for [[interstellar dust]] impacts.<ref name=BBC/> Unlike earlier internet-based citizen science projects such as [[SETI@home]], which used spare computer processing power to analyse data (also known as [[Distributed computing|distributed]] or volunteer computing), Stardust@home involved the active participation of human volunteers to complete the research task.<ref name="Nature">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/news/2007/070709/full/news070709-7.html |title=See new galaxies – without leaving your chair |journal=News@nature |last=Hopkin |first=Michael |date=11 July 2007 |doi=10.1038/news070709-7 |access-date=17 July 2014}}</ref> In August 2014, the Stardust team reported the discovery of first potential interstellar space particles after citizen scientists had looked through more than a million images.<ref name=NASA_SDSP>{{cite press release| | title=Stardust Team Reports Discovery of First Potential Interstellar Space Particles| date=August 14, 2014| publisher=[[NASA]]| url=http://www.nasa.gov/press/2014/august/stardust-team-reports-discovery-of-first-potential-interstellar-space-particles/| accessdate=September 4, 2014}}</ref>
When Galaxy Zoo first started, the science team hoped that 20–30,000 people would take part in classifying the 900,000 galaxies that made up the [[Sample (statistics)|sample]].<ref name=BBC/> It had been estimated that a perfect graduate student working 24 hours a day 7 days a week would take 3–5 years to classify all the galaxies in the sample once.<ref name="time"/> However, in the first Galaxy Zoo, more than 40 million classifications were made in approximately 175 days by more than 100,000 volunteers, providing an average of 38 classifications per galaxy.<ref name="GZ_1">{{Cite journal |last=Lintott |first=Chris |author-link=Chris Lintott |last2=Schawinski |first2=Kevin |author-link2=Kevin Schawinski |last3=Bamford |first3=Steven |last4=Slosar |first4=Anže |last5=Land |first5=Kate |last6=Thomas |first6=Daniel |last7=Edmondson |first7=Edd |last8=Masters |first8=Karen |last9=Nichol |first9=Robert C. |date=14 December 2010 |orig-year=3 Dec 2010 |title=Galaxy Zoo 1: data release of morphological classifications for nearly 900,000 galaxies |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=410 |issue=1 |pages=166–178 |arxiv=1007.3265 |bibcode=2011MNRAS.410..166L |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17432.x |first10=M. Jordan |last10=Raddick |first11=Alex |last11=Szalay |author-link11=Alex Szalay |first12=Dan |last12=Andreescu |first13=Phil |last13=Murray |first14=Jan |last14=Vandenberg}}</ref>
[[Chris Lintott]] commented that: "One advantage is that you get to see parts of space that have never been seen before. These images were taken by a [[robotic telescope]] and processed automatically, so the odds are that when you log on, that first galaxy you see will be one that no human has seen before."<ref name="BBC"/> This was confirmed by [[Kevin Schawinski]]: "Most of these galaxies have been photographed by a robotic telescope, and then processed by computer. So this is the first time they will have been seen by human eyes.".<ref name="Nature"/>
== Importance of volunteers == Galaxy Zoo recruited volunteers to help with the largest galaxy [[census]] ever carried out.<ref name="Nature"/> Opening the project to the general public saved the professional astronomers the task of studying all the galaxies themselves, resulting in classification of a large number of galaxies undertaken in a shorter time than what smaller research teams would be able to do, classifying 900,000 galaxies in months rather than years if done by smaller research teams.<ref name="Nature"/> [[Computer program]]s had been unable to reliably classify galaxies: several groups had attempted to develop image-analysis programs.<ref name="clery">{{Cite journal |last=Clery |first=D. |date=2011 |title=Galaxy Zoo Volunteers Share Pain and Glory of Research |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=333 |issue=6039 |pages=173–175 |bibcode=2011Sci...333..173C |doi=10.1126/science.333.6039.173 |pmid=21737731 }}</ref> [[Kevin Schawinski]] stated: "The human brain is actually much better than a computer at these [[pattern recognition]] tasks."<ref name="Nature"/><ref name="Banerji_1">{{Cite journal |last=Banerji |first=M. |last2=Lahav |first2=O. |last3=Lintott |first3=C. J. |last4=Abdalla |first4=F. B. |last5=Schawinski |first5=K. |last6=Bamford |first6=S. P. |last7=Andreescu |first7=D. |last8=Murray |first8=P. |last9=Raddick |first9=M. Jordan |date=2010 |title=Galaxy Zoo: reproducing galaxy morphologies via machine learning |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=406 |issue=1 |pages=342–353 |arxiv=0908.2033 |bibcode=2010MNRAS.406..342B |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.16713.x |first10=A. |last10=Slosar |first11=A. |last11=Szalay |first12=D. |last12=Thomas |first13=J. |last13=Vandenberg}}</ref> However, volunteers astonished the project’s organizers by classifying the entire catalog years ahead of schedule.<ref name=clery/> An online forum was later set up two weeks after the initial start, partially due to a large volume of emails being sent around, to the point that it was troublesome for those receiving them to process and respond to them. This led volunteers to point out anomalies that on closer inspection have turned out to be new astronomical objects such as '[[Hanny's Voorwerp]]' and '[[Pea galaxy|the Green Pea galaxies]]'.<ref name=clery/> “I’m incredibly impressed by what they’ve managed to achieve,” says University of Oxford astronomer [[Roger Davies (astrophysicist)|Roger Davies]], former president of the [[Royal Astronomical Society]].“They’ve made it possible to do things with a huge survey.”<ref name=clery/>
The Galaxy Zoo forum became a hotbed for the discussion of the SDSS images and more general science questions. Its 'global moderator', [[United Kingdom|UK]] teacher Alice Sheppard, said of it: "I don't quite know what it is, but Galaxy Zoo does something to people. The contributions, both creative and academic, that people have made to the forum are as stunning as the sight of any spiral, and never fail to move me."<ref name="nielsen">{{Cite book |title=Reinventing Discovery: The New Era of Networked Science |last= Nielsen |first=M. |date=2011 |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |isbn=978-0-691-14890-8}}</ref> Author [[Michael Nielsen]] wrote in his book [[Reinventing Discovery]]: "But Galaxy Zoo can go beyond computers, because it can also apply human intelligence in the analysis, the kind of intelligence that recognizes that Hanny's Voorwerp or a Pea galaxy is out of the ordinary, and deserves further investigation. Galaxy Zoo is thus a hybrid, able to do deep analyses of large data sets that are impossible in any other way."<ref name=nielsen/> A [[community]] feeling was also created. Roger Davies stated: "The community of Galaxy Zoo gives them the opportunity to participate that they’re looking for.”<ref name=clery/> This community became known as the 'Zooites'.<ref name="GalaxyBabe">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/dna/place-lancashire/plain/A25835880 |title=Galaxy Zoo - Amateurs Analysing Galaxies |last=Croft |first=Ann |date=16 August 2007 |access-date=13 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="Finkbeiner">{{Cite book |title=A Grand and Bold Thing: An Extraordinary New Map of the Universe Ushering In A New Era of Discovery |last= Finkbeiner |first=A. K. |date=2010 |publisher=[[Free Press (publisher)|Free Press]] |isbn=978-1416552161}}</ref> Aida Berges, a homemaker living in [[Puerto Rico]] who has classified hundreds of thousands of galaxies, stated: "Every galaxy has a story to tell. They are beautiful, mysterious, and show how amazing our [[universe]] is. It was love at first sight when I started in Galaxy Zoo ... It is a magical place, and it feels like coming home at last."<ref name="time"/><ref name=nielsen/> The Galaxy Zoo Forum became a read-only [[archive]] in July 2014. After seven years online and over 650,000 posts, it continues to generate science.
As of July 2017, 60 scientific papers have been published as a direct result of Galaxy Zoo and hundreds of thousands of volunteers.<ref name=BBC_GZ10/><ref name=Tw_GZ10/> In previous studies though, it was found that data produced by volunteers was more likely to contain [[bias (statistics)|bias]] or mistakes.<ref name="USA_today_1">{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/07/25/ozy-crowdsourcing-science/13143465/ |title=Crowdsourcing science goes boom |last=Palet |first=Laura |date=25 July 2014 |access-date=26 July 2014 |publisher=USA Today}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Thelen |first=Brett Amy |last2=Thiet |first2=Rachel K. |date=2008 |title=Cultivating connection: Incorporating meaningful citizen science into Cape Cod National Seashore's estuarine research and monitoring programs |url=http://www.nature.nps.gov/ParkScience/index.cfm?ArticleID=236&Page=1 |journal=Park Science |volume=25 |issue=1 |access-date=2012-10-11 |issn=1090-9966}}</ref><ref name="Zoon_Pubs">{{Cite web |url=https://www.zooniverse.org/publications |title=Zooniverse Publications |access-date=18 October 2016}}</ref> However Chris Lintott says that [[crowdsourcing|crowdsourced]] results are reliable, as proven by the fact that they are being used and published in [[peer review|peer-reviewed]] science papers.<ref name=USA_today_1/> Indeed, other scientists have questioned crowdsourcing and crowdsourced studies. Steven Bamford, a Galaxy Zoo research scientist, stated: "As a professional researcher you take pride in the work that you do. And the idea that anybody off the street could come and do something better sounds threatening but also implausible."<ref name=USA_today_1/> [[David P. Anderson|David Anderson]], the founder of [[BOINC]], stated: [For many sceptical scientists] "There's this idea that they're giving up control somehow, and that their importance would be diminished".<ref name="Nature_CiSci1">{{Cite journal |last=Hand |first=E. |date=2010 |title=Citizen science: People power |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=466 |issue=7307 |pages=685–7 |doi=10.1038/466685a |pmid=20686547}}</ref> The continuing goodwill of citizen scientists is also questioned. Chris Lintott stated: "Rather than letting anyone pitch for volunteers, we'd like to be a place where people can come and expect a certain level of commitment".<ref name=Nature_CiSci1/>
'''Tenth anniversary'''. A conference was held between July 10-12th 2017 at [[St Catherine's College, Oxford|St. Catherine's College]], [[Oxford]], to recognise the tenth anniversary of the start of Galaxy Zoo in July 2007.<ref name=BBC_GZ10>{{Cite news| title=Galaxy Zoo: Citizen science trailblazer marks tenth birthday| author=Richard Gray| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-40558759| publisher=BBC| date=11 July 2017| accessdate=17 July 2017| work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name=Zoon_GZ10>{{cite web| title=Celebrating 10 years of Galaxy Zoo| url=https://daily.zooniverse.org/2017/06/27/celebrating-10-years-of-galaxy-zoo| publisher=Daily Zooniverse| date=27 June 2017| accessdate=17 July 2017}}</ref><ref name=Yahoo_1>{{cite web| title=The Tenth anniversary of Galaxy Zoo and the citizen science revolution| author=Nicola Irwin| url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/10th-anniversary-galaxy-zoo-citizen-141722835.html| publisher=Yahoo| date=11 July 2017| accessdate=24 July 2017| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803172752/https://uk.news.yahoo.com/10th-anniversary-galaxy-zoo-citizen-141722835.html| archivedate=3 August 2017| df=dmy-all}}</ref> Co-founder Chris Lintott stated: "What started as a small project has been completely transformed by the enthusiasm and efforts of the volunteers... It has had a real impact on our understanding of galaxy evolution."<ref name=BBC_GZ10/> 125 million galaxy classifications resulting in 60 peer reviewed academic papers from at least 15 different projects have been made since July 2007.<ref name=BBC_GZ10/> Discoveries include:[[Hanny's Voorwerp]], [[Pea galaxy|Green pea galaxies]] and more recently objects known as 'Yellow Balls'.<ref name=BBC_GZ10/> On the conference Twitter feed, #GZ10, it states that 10 of the 60 papers have over 100 citations [within the [[Astrophysics Data System]]] in 10 years.<ref name=Tw_GZ10>{{cite web| title=GZoo10| url=https://twitter.com/hashtag/gzoo10?src=hash&lang=en| publisher=Twitter| date=12 July 2017| accessdate=17 July 2017}}</ref> [[Karen Masters]], an astrophysicist at [[Portsmouth University]] and project scientist for GZ stated: "We're genuinely asking for help with something we cannot do ourselves and the results have made a big contribution to the field."<ref name=BBC_GZ10/> As a result of GZ's success, the [[citizen science]] web portal [[Zooniverse]] was started, which has since hosted a 100 projects.<ref name=BBC_GZ10/>
== Retired projects ==
=== Galaxy Zoo 1 === The original Galaxy Zoo consisted of a data set made up of ≈900,000 galaxies imaged by the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]]. With so many galaxies, it had been assumed that it would take years for visitors to the site to work through them all, but within 24 hours of launch, the website was receiving almost 70,000 classifications an hour. In the end, more than 50 million classifications were received by the project during its first year, contributed by more than 150,000 people. This was started in July 2007 and retired in 2009.<ref name=GZ_1/>
=== Galaxy Zoo 2 === This consisted of some 250,000 of the brightest galaxies from the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]].<ref name="GZ_2">{{Cite journal |last=Willett |first=Kyle W. |last2=Lintott |first2=Chris J. |author-link2=Chris Lintott |last3=Bamford |first3=Steven P. |last4=Masters |first4=Karen L. |last5=Simmons |first5=Brooke D. |last6=Casteels |first6=Kevin R. V. |last7=Edmondson |first7=Edward M. |last8=Fortson |first8=Lucy F. |last9=Kaviraj |first9=Sugata |date=16 September 2013 |orig-year=19 Aug 2013 |title=Galaxy Zoo 2: detailed morphological classifications for 304,122 galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=435 |issue=4 |pages=2835–2860 |arxiv=1308.3496 |bibcode=2013MNRAS.435.2835W |doi=10.1093/mnras/stt1458 |first10=William C. |last10=Keel |first11=Thomas |last11=Melvin |first12=Robert C. |last12=Nichol |first13=M. Jordan |last13=Raddick |first14=Kevin |last14=Schawinski |authorlink14=Kevin Schawinski |first15=Robert J. |last15=Simpson |first16=Ramin A. |last16=Skibba |first17=Arfon M. |last17=Smith |first18=Daniel |last18=Thomas}}</ref> Galaxy Zoo 2 allowed for a much more detailed classification, by shape and by the intensity or dimness of the galactic [[Bulge (astronomy)|core]], and with a special section for oddities like mergers or [[ring galaxy|ring galaxies]].<ref name="GZ_PolarRing">{{Cite journal |last=Finkelman |first=I. |last2=Funes |first2=J. G. |last3=Brosch |first3=N. |date=2012 |title=Polar ring galaxies in the Galaxy Zoo |journal=MNRAS |volume=422 |issue=3 |pages=2386–2398 |arxiv=1202.5033 |bibcode=2012MNRAS.422.2386F |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.20790.x}}</ref> The sample also contained fewer optical oddities. The project closed with some 60 million classifications.<ref name=GZ_2/>
=== Galaxy Zoo mergers === This studied the role of interacting galaxies. Interacting galaxies are galaxies that exhibit a gravitational influence on one another. This influence is exhibited over the course of millions or even billions of years as two or more galaxies pass nearby one another. The near passage of two massive structures can cause the galaxies to be distorted and possibly merge. The Galaxy Zoo Mergers aimed to provide a set of tools that allowed users to randomly sample various sets of simulation parameters in rapid succession by showing 8 simulation outputs at a time. This started in November 2009 and was retired in June 2012.<ref name="IOP_merger">{{Cite web |url=http://physicsworld.com/blog/2009/11/galaxy_zoo_mergers.html |title='Galaxy Zoo Mergers' opens today |last=Johnston |first=Hamish |publisher=[[Institute of Physics]] |access-date=17 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="BBC_merger">{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8376566.stm |title=Astronomers release galactic collision game |access-date=17 July 2014}}</ref>
=== Galaxy Zoo supernovae === Galaxy Zoo used images partner from the Palomar Transient Factory to find Supernovae. The task in this Galaxy Zoo project was to help catch exploding stars – supernovae. Data for the site was provided by an automatic survey in California at the Palomar Observatory. Astronomers followed up on the best candidates at telescopes around the world. This started in August 2009 and was retired in August 2012.<ref name="GZ_Supernovae">{{Cite journal |last=Smith |first=A. M. |last2=Lynn |first2=S. |last3=Sullivan |first3=M. |last4=Lintott |first4=C. J. |last5=Nugent |first5=P. E. |last6=Botyanszki |first6=J. |last7=Kasliwal |first7=M. |last8=Quimby |first8=R. |last9=Bamford |first9=S. P. |date=2011 |title=Galaxy Zoo Supernovae |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=412 |issue=2 |pages=1309 |arxiv=1011.2199 |bibcode=2011MNRAS.412.1309S |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17994.x |first10=L. F. |last10=Fortson |first11=K. |last11=Schawinski |first12=I. |last12=Hook |first13=S. |last13=Blake |first14=P. |last14=Podsiadlowski |first15=J. |last15=Joensson |first16=A. |last16=Gal-Yam |first17=I. |last17=Arcavi |first18=D. A. |last18=Howell |first19=J. S. |last19=Bloom |first20=J. |last20=Jacobsen |first21=S. R. |last21=Kulkarni |first22=N.M. |last22=Law |first23=E.O. |last23=Ofek |first24=R. |last24=Walters}}</ref><ref name="Simpson_1">{{Cite paper |last=Simpson |first=Edwin |last2=Roberts |first2=Stephen |last3=Psorakis |first3=Ioannis |last4=Smith |first4=Arfon |date=8 Jun 2012 |title=Dynamic Bayesian Combination of Multiple Imperfect Classifiers |arxiv=1206.1831v1}}</ref>
=== Galaxy Zoo Hubble === The site’s third incarnation, Galaxy Zoo Hubble drew from surveys conducted by the Hubble Space Telescope to view earlier epochs of galaxy formation. In these surveys, which involve many days of dedicated observing time, we can see light from galaxies which has taken billions of years to reach us. The idea behind Galaxy Zoo Hubble was to be able to compare galaxies then to galaxies now, giving us a clear understanding of what factors influence their growth, whether through mergers, active black holes or simply star formation. This started in April 2010 and was retired in September 2012.<ref name="Hubble_1">{{Cite journal |last=Melvin |first=T. |last2=Masters |first2=K. |last3=Lintott |first3=C. |author-link3=Chris Lintott |last4=Nichol |first4=R. C. |last5=Simmons |first5=B. |last6=Bamford |first6=S. P. |last7=Casteels |first7=K. R. V. |last8=Cheung |first8=E. |last9=Edmondson |first9=E. M. |date=2014 |title=Galaxy Zoo: an independent look at the evolution of the bar fraction over the last eight billion years from HST-COSMOS |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=438 |issue=4 |pages=2882–2897 |arxiv=1401.3334 |bibcode=2014MNRAS.438.2882M |doi=10.1093/mnras/stt2397 |first10=L. |last10=Fortson |first11=K. |last11=Schawinski |author-link11=Kevin Schawinski |first12=R. A. |last12=Skibba |first13=A. M. |last13=Smith |first14=K. W. |last14=Willett}} </ref>
In October 2016, a study titled: "Galaxy Zoo: Morphological Classifications for 120,000 Galaxies in HST Legacy Imaging" was accepted for publication by the journal [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]].<ref name="GZH_2016">{{Cite journal |last=Willett |first=K. W. |last2=Galloway |first2=M. A. |last3=Bamford |first3=S. P. |last4=Lintott |first4=C. J. |author-link4=Chris Lintott |last5=Masters |first5=K. L. |last6=Scarlata |first6=C. |last7=Simmons |first7=B. D. |last8=Beck |first8=M. |last9=Cardamone |first9=C. N. |date=10 October 2016 |title=Galaxy Zoo: Morphological Classifications for 120,000 Galaxies in HST Legacy Imaging |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society |volume=464 |issue=4 |pages=4176–4203 |arxiv=1610.03068 |bibcode=2017MNRAS.464.4176W |doi=10.1093/mnras/stw2568 |first10=E. |last10=Cheung |first11=E. M. |last11=Edmondson |first12=L. F. |last12=Fortson |first13=R. L. |last13=Griffith |first14=B. |last14=Haeussler |first15=A. |last15=Han |first16=R. |last16=Hart |first17=T. |last17=Melvin |first18=M.| last18=Parrish |first19=K. |last19=Schawinski |first20=R. J. |last20=Smethurst |first21=A.M. |last21=Smith}}</ref> The abstract begins: "We present the data release paper for the Galaxy Zoo: Hubble project. This is the third phase in a large effort to measure reliable, detailed morphologies of galaxies by using crowdsourced visual classifications of colour composite images. Images in Galaxy Zoo Hubble were selected from various publicly-released Hubble Space Telescope Legacy programs conducted with the Advanced Camera for Surveys, with filters that probe the rest- frame optical emission from galaxies out to z ≈1."<ref name=GZH_2016/>
=== Galaxy Zoo 4 === The present Galaxy Zoo (4) combines new imaging from the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]] with the most distant images yet from the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] [[CANDELS]] survey. The CANDELS survey makes use of the new [[Wide Field Camera 3]] to take ultra-deep images of the universe. The project also includes images taken with the [[United Kingdom Infrared Telescope]] in Hawaii, for the recently completed [[UKIDSS]] project. UKIDSS is the largest, deepest survey of the sky at infrared wavelengths.<ref name="GZ4_OxPR">{{Cite news |url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/news/2012-09-11-public-maps-out-z-galaxies |title=Public maps out an A to Z of galaxies |date=11 September 2012 |access-date=13 October 2016 |publisher=University of Oxford}}</ref> [[Kevin Schawinski]] explained that: "The two sources of data work together perfectly: the new images from [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey|Sloan]] give us our most detailed view of the local universe, while the CANDELS survey from the Hubble telescope allows us to look deeper into the universe’s past than ever before."<ref name=GZ4_OxPR/>
In October 2016, a paper was accepted for publishing in [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|MNRAS]] titled: "Galaxy Zoo: Quantitative Visual Morphological Classifications for 48,000 galaxies from CANDELS".<ref name="GZ_CANDELS">{{Cite journal |last=Simmons |first=B. D. |last2=Lintott |first2=C. |last3= Willett |first3=K. W. |last4= Masters |first4=K .L. |last5= Kartaltepe |first5=J. Each galaxy received an average of 40 independent classifications, which we combine into detailed morphological information on galaxy features such as clumpiness, bar instabilities, spiral structure, and merger and tidal signatures."<ref name=GZ_CANDELS/>
== Active projects ==
=== Radio Galaxy Zoo ===
{{main| Radio Galaxy Zoo}} On December 17, 2013, Galaxy Zoo opened a project called Radio Galaxy Zoo. It uses observations from the [[Australian Astronomical Observatory|Australia Telescope Large Area Survey]] in Radio, and compares them to the [[Spitzer Space Telescope]]'s infrared data. There are about 6000 images to look through.<ref name="RGZ">{{Cite web |url=https://csiropedia.csiro.au/find-black-holes-while-youre-on-the-bus |title=Find black holes while you're on the bus |date=18 December 2013 |publisher=Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation |access-date=18 October 2016}}</ref> The [[CSIRO]] press release states that Radio Galaxy Zoo is a new citizen science project that lets anyone become a cosmic explorer. It continues that by matching galaxy images with radio images from CSIRO’s Australia Telescope, a participant can work out if a galaxy has a [[supermassive black hole]].<ref name="RGZ"/>
=== Other ongoing projects === Another project that uses data from volunteer classifications is Galaxy Zoo Quench, which studies the interactions between galaxies and the effect it has on starbursts (among others).<ref name=Red_Herring/><ref name="Wong_1">{{Cite journal |last=Wong |first=O. Ivy |last2=Schawinski |first2=K. |last3=Kaviraj |first3=S. |last4=Masters |first4=K. L. |last5=Nichol |first5=R.C. |last6=Lintott |first6=C.J. |last7=Keel |first7=W.C. |last8=Darg |first8=D. |last9=Bamford |first9=S.P. |date=2012 |title=Galaxy Zoo: building the low-mass end of the red sequence with local post-starburst galaxies |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=420 |issue=2 |pages=1684–1692 |arxiv=1111.1785 |bibcode=2012MNRAS.420.1684W |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20159.x |first10=D. |last10=Andreescu |first11=P. |last11=Murray |first12=M. J. |last12=Raddick |first13=A. |last13=Szalay |first14=D. |last14=Thomas |first15=J. |last15=VandenBerg}}</ref> This has yet to be completed.
=== Complete list of projects ===
As of July 2017, the full list of Galaxy Zoo projects (15) is: Galaxy Zoo 1, Galaxy Zoo 2, Galaxy Zoo Mergers, Galaxy Zoo Supernovae, Galaxy Zoo Hubble, Galaxy Zoo CANDELS, Radio Galaxy Zoo, Galaxy Zoo Quench, Galaxy Zoo DECALS 1, Galaxy Zoo DECALS2 + SDSS, Illustris, UKIDSS, Galaxy Zoo Bar Lengths and two more.<ref name=BBC_GZ10/>
== Rotation of galaxies == [[File:Pinwheel Galaxy CW or ACW.jpg|thumb|[[clockwise|CW]] or [[anticlockwise|ACW]]? This [[Hubble Space Telescope|HST]] image of Messier 101, the [[Pinwheel galaxy]] has it in its normal orientation and then reversed.]] One of the original aims for Galaxy Zoo was to explore which way galaxies rotated. Cosmologist Kate Land stated: "Some people have argued that galaxies are rotating all in agreement with each other, not randomly as we'd expect. We want people to classify the galaxies according to which way they're rotating and I'll be able to go and see if there's anything bizarre going on. If there are any patterns that we're not expecting, it could really turn up some surprises."<ref name="BBC"/> In Galaxy Zoo 1, volunteers were asked to judge from the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey|SDSS]] images whether the galaxies were [[elliptical galaxy|elliptical]] or [[spiral galaxy|spiral]] and, if spiral, whether they were rotating in a [[clockwise]] or [[anti-clockwise]] direction. The rotation, also called the [[Chirality]], of galaxies has been examined in several Galaxy Zoo related papers.<ref name=Land_Chirality>{{ cite journal|author1=K. Land |author2=A. Slosar |author3=C. Lintott |author4=D. Andreescu |author5=S. Bamford |author6=P. Murray |author7=R. Nichol |author8=M.Jordan Raddick |author9=K. Schawinski |author10=A. Szalay |author11=D. Thomas |author12=J. Vandenberg | date=2008| title=Galaxy Zoo: the large-scale spin statistics of spiral galaxies in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=388| issue=4| bibcode=2008MNRAS.388.1686L| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.13490.x|arxiv=0803.3247 | pages=1686–1692}}</ref><ref name=Slosar_Chirality>{{ cite journal|author1=A. Slosar |author2=K. Land |author3=S. Bamford |author4=C. Lintott |author5=D. Andreescu |author6=P. Murray |author7=R. Nichol |author8=M. Jordan Raddick |author9=K. Schawinski |author10=A. Szalay |author11=D. Thomas |author12=J. Vandenberg | date=2009| title=Galaxy Zoo: chiral correlation function of galaxy spins| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=392| issue=3|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.14127.x| bibcode=2009MNRAS.392.1225S| arxiv=0809.0717 | pages=1225–1232}}</ref><ref name=Jimenez_Chirality>{{ cite journal|author1=R. Jimenez |author2=A. Slosar |author3=L. Verde |author4=S. Bamford |author5=C. Lintott |author6=K. Schawinski |author7=R. Nichol |author8=D. Andreescu |author9=K. Land |author10=P. Murray |author11=M. Jordan Raddick |author12=A. Szalay |author13=D. Thomas |author14=J. Vandenberg | date=2010| title=Galaxy Zoo: a correlation between the coherence of galaxy spin chirality and star formation efficiency| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=404| issue=2| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.16336.x| bibcode=2010MNRAS.404..975J| arxiv=0906.0994 | pages=975–980}}</ref>
Among the results a psychological bias was demonstrated.<ref name=Land_Chirality/> Galaxy Zoo scientists had wanted to check whether spiral galaxies were evenly distributed or whether there was some intrinsic property of the Universe that caused galaxies to rotate one way or the other. When the Science team came to analyse the results they found an excess of anti-clockwise spinning spiral galaxies.<ref name=Land_Chirality/> But when the team checked this bias by asking volunteers to classify the same image which had then been reversed, there was still an excess of anti-clockwise classifications. This demonstrated that the human brain has real difficultly discerning between something rotating clockwise or anti-clockwise.<ref name=Land_Chirality/> Having measured this effect the team could adjust for it, and went on to establish that spirals which were near each other tended to rotate in the same direction.<ref name=Land_Chirality/>
== Blue ellipticals and red spirals == Mainstream astronomical theory before Galaxy Zoo held that [[elliptical galaxy|elliptical]] (or 'early type') galaxies were red in color and [[spiral galaxy|spiral]] (or 'late type') galaxies were blue in color: several papers published as a result of Galaxy Zoo have proved otherwise.<ref name=Red_Herring>{{cite journal| authors=K. Schawinski, C. Megan Urry, B.D. Simmons, L. Fortson, S. Kaviraj, W.C. Keel, C.J. Lintott, K.L. Masters, R.C. Nichol, M. Sarzi, Ramin S., E. Treister, K.W. Willett, O.I.Wong, Sukyoung K.Y.| date=2014| title=The green valley is a red herring: Galaxy Zoo reveals two evolutionary pathways towards quenching of star formation in early- and late-type galaxies| journal=[[MNRAS]]| bibcode=2014MNRAS.440..889S| doi=10.1093/mnras/stu327| arxiv=1402.4814| volume=440| issue=1| pages=889–907}}</ref><ref name=Early_Blues>{{cite journal| author=K. Schawinski, C. Lintott, D. Thomas, M. Sarzi, D. Andreescu, S.P. Bamford, S. Kaviraj, S. Khochfar, K. Land, P. Murray, R.C. Nichol, M. Jordan Raddick, A. Slosar, A.Szalay, J. Vanden Berg, Sukyoung K. Yi| date=2009| title=Galaxy Zoo: a sample of blue early-type galaxies at low redshift|journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=396| issue=2| bibcode=2009MNRAS.396..818S| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.14793.x| arxiv=0903.3415| pages=818–829}}</ref><ref name=Red_Spirals>{{cite journal|author1=K.L. Masters |author2=M. Mosleh |author3=A.K. Romer |author4=R.C. Nichol |author5=S.P. Bamford |author6=K. Schawinski |author7=C.J. Lintott |author8=D. Andreescu |author9=H.C. Campbell |author10=B. Crowcroft |author11=I. Doyle |author12=E.M. Edmondson |author13=P. Murray |author14=M. Jordan Raddick |author15=A. Slosar |author16=A.S. Szalay |author17=J.Vanden Berg | date=2010| title=Galaxy Zoo: passive red spirals|journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=405| issue=2|pages=783 | bibcode=2010MNRAS.405..783M| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.16503.x| arxiv=0910.4113}}</ref><ref name=Tojeiro>{{cite journal|author1=R. Tojeiro |author2=K.L. Masters |author3=J. Richards |author4=W.J. Percival |author5=S.P. Bamford |author6=C. Maraston |author7=R.C. Nichol |author8=R. Skibba |author9=D. Thomas | date=2013| title=The different star formation histories of blue and red spiral and elliptical galaxies| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=432| issue=1| bibcode=2013MNRAS.432..359T| doi=10.1093/mnras/stt484| arxiv=1303.3551 | pages=359–373}}</ref> A population of blue ellipticals was found.<ref name=Early_Blues/> These are galaxies which have changed their shape from spiral to oval, but still have young stars in them.<ref name=Early_Blues/> Indeed, Galaxy Zoo came about through Schawinski's searching for blue elliptical galaxies, as near the end of 2006, he had spent most of his waking hours trying to find these rare galaxies.<ref name=JoHop_1>{{cite web| last=Powell| first=Devin| title=Amateur Hour| publisher=Johns Hopkins University| url=http://krieger.jhu.edu/magazine/sp08/f1.html| date=Spring 2008| volume=5|issue=2| accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref> Blueness in galaxies means that new stars are forming. However ellipticals are almost always red, indicating that they are full of old and dead stars.<ref name=JoHop_1/> Thus, blue ellipticals are paradoxical, but give clues to star-formation in different types of galaxies.<ref name=JoHop_1/>
Also, a population of red spirals mean was found.<ref name=Red_Spirals/> These have a different evolutionary path from normal spiral galaxies, showing red spiral galaxies can stop making new stars without changing their shape.<ref name=Red_Spirals/> Using Galaxy Zoo data for their sample, Tojeiro et al. 2013 find (pg.5): 13959 red ellipticals, 381 blue ellipticals, 5139 blue late-type spirals, 294 red late-type spirals, 1144 blue early-type spirals, and 1265 red early-type spirals.<ref name=Tojeiro/> Chris Lintott stated: "These red spiral galaxies had been lurking in the data and no-one had spotted them. They were staring us in the face. Now we know that a third of spirals around the edges of some clusters of galaxies are red."<ref name=skymania>{{cite web|last=Sutherland| first=Paul| title=Space fans find new breed of galaxy| url=http://www.skymania.com/wp/2008/11/space-fans-find-new-breed-of-galaxy.html| publisher=skymania| date=November 24, 2008| accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref> He also stated: "These results are possible thanks to a major scientific contribution from our many volunteer armchair astronomers. No group of professionals could have classified this many galaxies alone."<ref name=ScDaRedSpirals>{{cite web| publisher=sciencedaily| title=Strangulation Of Spiral Galaxies: 'Missing Link' Discovered| url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2008/11/081124194936.htm| date=November 25, 2008| accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> A team using the [[Hubble Space telescope]] has independently verified the existence of red spirals.<ref name=STAGES>{{cite journal| author=C. Wolf, A. Aragon-Salamanca, M. Balogh, M. Barden, E.F. Bell, M.E. Gray, C.Y. Peng, D. Bacon, F.D. Barazza, A. Boehm, J.A.R. Caldwell, A. Gallazzi, B. and 12 others| date=2009|title=The STAGES view of red spirals and dusty red galaxies: mass-dependent quenching of star formation in cluster infall| journal=[[MNRAS]]| bibcode=2009MNRAS.393.1302W| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.14204.x| arxiv=0811.3873| volume=393| issue=4| pages=1302–1323}}</ref> Meghan Gray stated: "Our two projects have approached the problem from very different directions. It is gratifying to see that we each provide independent pieces of the puzzle pointing to the same conclusion."<ref name=skymania/><ref name=ScDaRedSpirals/>
It is thought that Red Spirals are galaxies in the process of transition from young to old.<ref name=Uni_Today1>{{cite web| last=Atkinson| first=Nancy| title=Unusual Red Spiral Galaxies "Strangled"| publisher=Universe Today| url=http://www.universetoday.com/21457/unusual-red-spiral-galaxies-strangled/|date=November 25, 2008| accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref> They are more massive than blue spirals and are found on the outskirts of large [[Galaxy cluster|clusters]] of galaxies. Chris Lintott stated: "We think what we’re seeing is galaxies that have been gently strangled, so to speak, where somehow the gas supply for star formation has been cut off, but that they’ve been strangled so gently that the arms are still there."<ref name=Uni_Today1/> The cause might be the Red Spiral's gentle interaction with a galaxy cluster. He further explained: "The kind of thing we’re imagining [is that] as the galaxy moves into a denser environment, there’s lot of gas in clusters as well as galaxies, and it’s possible the gas from the galaxy just gets stripped off by the denser medium it’s plowing into."<ref name=Uni_Today1/>
== Dust in galaxies == [[File:Ngc3314.jpg|thumb|right|[[Hubble Space Telescope|HST]] image of [[NGC 3314]], an example of an overlapping galaxy.]] The properties of [[Interstellar medium|Galactic Dust]] have been examined in several Galaxy Zoo papers.<ref name=Masters_Dust1>{{cite journal| author=K.L. Masters, R.C. Nichol, S. Bamford, M. Mosleh, C.J. Lintott, D. Andreescu, E.M. Edmondson, W.C. Keel and 7 others | date=2010| title=Galaxy Zoo: dust in spiral galaxies| journal=MNRAS| volume=404| issue=1| bibcode=2010MNRAS.404..792M| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.16335.x| arxiv=1001.1744| pages=792–810}}</ref><ref name=Shabala_Dust_Mergers>{{cite journal| authors=S.S. Shabala, Y-S Ting, S.Kaviraj, C. Lintott, R.M. Crockett, J. Silk, M. Sarzi, K. Schawinski, S. P. Bamford, E. Edmondson| date=2012| title=Galaxy Zoo: dust lane early-type galaxies are tracers of recent, gas-rich minor mergers| journal=[[MNRAS]]| bibcode=2012MNRAS.423...59S| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.20598.x| arxiv=1107.5310| volume=423| issue=1| pages=59–67}}</ref><ref name=Kaviraj_Dust>{{cite journal| author=S. Kaviraj, Y-S. Ting, M. Bureau, S.S. Shabala, R.M. Crockett, J. Silk, C.J. Lintott, A. Smith, W.C. Keel, K.L. Masters, K. Schawinski, S.P. Bamford| date=2012| title=Galaxy Zoo: dust and molecular gas in early-type galaxies with prominent dust lanes| journal=[[MNRAS]]| bibcode=2012MNRAS.423...49K| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.20957.x| arxiv=1107.5306| volume=423| issue=1| pages=49–58}}</ref><ref name=Keel_Overlap1>{{cite journal|author1=W.C. Keel |author2=A. Manning |author3=B.W. Holwerda |author4=M. Mezzoprete |author5=C.J. Lintott |author6=K. Schawinski |author7=P. Gay |author8=K.L. Masters | date=2013| title=Galaxy Zoo: A Catalog of Overlapping Galaxy Pairs for Dust Studies| journal=[[Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific]]| bibcode=2013PASP..125....2K| doi=10.1086/669233|arxiv=1211.6723 | volume=125 |issue=923 | pages=2–16}}</ref> The [[interstellar medium]] of spiral galaxies is filled by gas and small solid particles called dust grains. Despite constituting only a minor fraction of the galactic mass (between 0.1% and 0.01% for the Milky Way), dust grains have a major role in shaping the appearance of a galaxy. Because of their dimension (typically smaller than a few tenths of a [[micron]]), they are very effective in absorbing and scattering the radiation emitted by stars in the [[ultraviolet]], [[optics|optical]] and [[near-infrared]].<ref name=ESF_Workshop>{{ cite web| title=Tracing Dust in Spiral Galaxies: radiative transfer studies in the dawn of a new generation of observing facilities| url=http://www.arcetri.astro.it/radtran/sci.html| publisher=[[European Science Foundation]]| date=May 14–16, 2007| accessdate= 22 July 2014}}</ref> Although the interstellar regions are more devoid of matter than any [[vacuum]] artificially created on earth, there is matter in space. These regions have very low densities and consist mainly of gas (99%) and dust. In total, approximately 15% of the visible matter in the Milky Way is composed of interstellar gas and dust.<ref name=ISM_NewHampshire>{{cite web| title=The Interstellar Medium| url=http://www-ssg.sr.unh.edu/ism/what1.html| publisher=[[The University of New Hampshire]]| accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref>
The study of dust in galaxies is interesting for many reasons.<ref name=NS_Dust>{{cite news| author=Natalie Starkey| title=Your house is full of space dust – it reveals the solar system’s story| url=http://theconversation.com/your-house-is-full-of-space-dust-it-reveals-the-solar-systems-story-20270| publisher=The Conversation| date=22 November 2013| access-date=18 October 2016}}</ref> For example, the dimming effects of dust need to be corrected for to estimate the total mass of a galaxy from measurements of its light. Standard candles used to measure the expansion history of the Universe also need to be corrected for dust extinction.
A catalogue of 1,990 overlapping galaxies was published in 2013, which had been collected by volunteers on the Galaxy Zoo forum using SDSS images. The abstract states: 'Analysis of galaxies with overlapping images offers a direct way to probe the distribution of dust extinction and its effects on the background light.'<ref name=Keel_Overlap1/> This catalogue was also used in a study of [[ultraviolet]] attenuation laws.<ref name=Keel_Overlap2>{{cite journal|author1=W.C. Keel |author2=A.M. Manning |author3=B.W. Holwerda |author4=C.J. Lintott |author5=K. Schawinski | date=2014| title=The Ultraviolet Attenuation Law in Backlit Spiral Galaxies| journal=[[The Astronomical Journal]]| bibcode=2014AJ....147...44K| doi=10.1088/0004-6256/147/2/44| arxiv=1401.0773 | volume=147 |issue=2 | pages=44}}</ref>
== Galactic bars and bulges == [[File:Hubble2005-01-barred-spiral-galaxy-NGC1300.jpg|thumb|right| A [[Hubble Space Telescope|HST]] image of [[NGC 1300]], a typical barred spiral]] Some [[Spiral galaxy|spiral galaxies]] have central bar-shaped structures composed of stars. These galaxies are called [[Barred spiral galaxy|'barred spirals']] and have been investigated by Galaxy Zoo in several studies.<ref name=Masters_Bar1>{{cite journal|author1=K.L. Masters |author2=R.C. Nichol |author3=B. Hoyle |author4=C.J. Lintott |author5=S. Bamford |author6=E.M. Edmondson |author7=L. Fortson |author8=W.C. Keel |author9=K. Schawinski |author10=A. Smith |author11=D. Thomas. | date=2011| title=Galaxy Zoo: bars in disc galaxies| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=411| issue=3 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17834.x| arxiv=1003.0449|bibcode = 2011MNRAS.411.2026M | pages=2026–2034}}</ref><ref name=Hoyle_1>{{cite journal| author=B. Hoyle, K.L. Masters, R.C. Nichol, E.M. Edmondson, A.M. Smith, C.J.Lintott, R. Scranton, S. Bamford, K. Schawinski, D. Thomas| date=2011| title=Galaxy Zoo: bar lengths in local disc galaxies| journal=MNRAS| volume=415| issue=4| bibcode=2011MNRAS.415.3627H| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18979.x| arxiv=1104.5394| pages=3627–3640}}</ref><ref name=Masters_Bar2>{{ cite journal|author1=K.L. Masters |author2=R.C. Nichol |author3=M.P. Haynes |author4=W.C. Keel |author5=C.J. Lintott |author6=B. Simmons |author7=R. Skibba |author8=S. Bamford |author9=R. Giovanelli |author10=K. Schawinski | date=2012| title=Galaxy Zoo and ALFALFA: atomic gas and the regulation of star formation in barred disc galaxies| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=424| issue=3| bibcode=2012MNRAS.424.2180M| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.21377.x| arxiv=1205.5271 | pages=2180–2192}}</ref><ref name=Cheung_1>{{ cite journal|author1=E. Cheung |author2=E. Athanassoula |author3=K.L. Masters |author4=R.C. Nichol |author5=A. Bosma |author6=E.F. Bell |author7=S.M. Faber |author8=D.C. Koo |author9=C.J. Lintott |author10=T. Melvin |author11=K. Schawinski |author12=R.A. Skibba |author13=K.W. Willett | date=2013| title=Galaxy Zoo: Observing Secular Evolution through Bars| journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]]| volume=779| issue=2| bibcode=2013ApJ...779..162C| doi=10.1088/0004-637X/779/2/162| arxiv=1310.2941 | pages=162}}</ref> It is unclear why some spiral galaxies have bars and some do not.<ref name=ScDaBars_1>{{cite web| publisher=sciencedaily| title=Bars kill spiral galaxies, astronomers and volunteers discover| url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/11/101108191613.htm| date=November 9, 2010| accessdate=23 July 2014}}</ref> Galaxy Zoo research has shown that red spirals are about twice as likely to host bars as blue spirals. These colours are significant. Blue galaxies get their hue from the hot young stars they contain, implying that they are forming stars in large numbers. In red galaxies, this star formation has stopped, leaving behind the cooler, long-lived stars that give them their red colour.<ref name=ScDaBars_1/>[[File:N4536s-crop.jpg|thumb|left| A [[Mount Lemmon Observatory|MLO]] image of bulgeless galaxy [[NGC 4536]].]] Karen Masters, a scientist involved in the studies, stated: "For some time data have hinted that spirals with more old stars are more likely to have bars, but with such a large number of bar classifications we're much more confident about our results. It's not yet clear whether the bars are some side effect of an external process that turns spiral galaxies red, or if they alone can cause this transformation."<ref name=ScDaBars_1/>
Spiral galaxies usually have 'bulges' at their centers. These bulges are huge, tightly packed groups of stars. However, using Galaxy Zoo volunteer classifications, it has been found that some spiral galaxies do not have bulges.<ref name=Simmons_1>{{ cite journal|author1=B.D. Simmons |author2=C.J. Lintott |author3=K. Schawinski |author4=E.C. Moran |author5=A. Han |author6=S. Kaviraj |author7=K.L. Masters |author8=C.M. Urry |author9=K.W. Willett |author10=S.P. Bamford |author11=R.C. Nichol | date=2013| title=Galaxy Zoo: bulgeless galaxies with growing black holes| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=429| issue=3| bibcode=2013MNRAS.429.2199S| doi=10.1093/mnras/sts491| arxiv=1207.4190 | pages=2199–2211}}</ref><ref name=Skibba_1>{{ cite journal|author1=R.A. Skibba |author2=K.L. Masters |author3=R.C. Nichol |author4=I. Zehavi |author5=B. Hoyle |author6=E.M. Edmondson |author7=S.P. Bamford |author8=C.N. Cardamone |author9=W.C. Keel |author10=C.J. Lintott |author11=K. Schawinski | date=2012| title=Galaxy Zoo: the environmental dependence of bars and bulges in disc galaxies| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=423| issue=2| bibcode=2012MNRAS.423.1485S| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.20972.x| arxiv=1111.0969 | pages=1485–1502}}</ref> Many galactic bulges are thought to host a [[supermassive black hole]] at their centers: however pure disk galaxies with no bulges but with growing central black holes were found.<ref name=Simmons_1/> That pure disk galaxies and their central black holes may be consistent with a relation derived from elliptical and bulge-dominated galaxies with very different formation histories implies the details of stellar galaxy evolution and dynamics may not be fundamental to the co-evolution of galaxies and black holes.<ref name=Simmons_1/> It seems that these bulgeless galaxies have formed in environments isolated from other galaxies.<ref name=AsBi_Bulgeless>{{cite web| last=Smethurst| first=Becky| title=Bulgeless galaxies with growing black holes| url=http://astrobites.org/2014/03/20/bulgeless-galaxies-with-growing-black-holes| publisher=astrobites| date=March 20, 2014| accessdate=23 July 2014}}</ref> It is hypothesised that the black hole mass may be more tightly tied to the overall gravitational potential of a galaxy and therefore its [[dark matter]] halo, rather than to the dynamical bulge component.<ref name=AsBi_Bulgeless/>
In September 2014, a paper titled: "Galaxy Zoo: CANDELS Barred Disks and Bar Fractions" was accepted for publication by the [[MNRAS]].<ref name=CanBars_1>{{cite journal|author1=B.D. Simmons |author2=T. Melvin |author3=C.J. Lintott |author4=K.L. Masters |author5=K.W. Willett |author6=W.C. Keel |author7=R.J. Smethurst |author8=E. Cheung |author9=R.C. Nichol |author10=K. Schawinski |author11=M. Rutkowski |author12=J.S. Kartaltepe |author13=E.F. Bell |author14=K.R.V. Casteels |author15=C.J. Conselice |author16=O. Almaini |author17=H.C. Ferguson |author18=L. Fortson |author19=W. Hartley |author20=D. Kocevski |author21=A.M. Koekemoer |author22=D.H. McIntosh |author23=A. Mortlock |author24=J.A. Newman |author25=J. Ownsworth |author26=S. Bamford |author27=T. Dahlen |author28=S.M. Faber |author29=S.L. Finkelstein |author30=A. Fontana |author31=A. Galametz |author32=N.A. Grogin |author33=R. Grutzbauch |author34=Y. Guo |author35=B. Haussler |author36=K.J. Jek |author37=S. Kaviraj |author38=R. A. Lucas |author39=M. Peth |author40=M. Salvato |author41=T. Wiklind |author42=S. Wuyts | title=Galaxy Zoo: CANDELS Barred Disks and Bar Fractions| date=September 2014| arxiv=1409.1214 | doi=10.1093/mnras/stu1817 | volume=445 |issue=4 | journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society | pages=3466–3474|bibcode = 2014MNRAS.445.3466S }}</ref> This was the first set of results from the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] [[CANDELS]] survey that was part of Galaxy Zoo 4. The study reports "the discovery of strong barred structures in massive disk galaxies at z ≈1.5 in deep rest-frame optical images from CANDELS".<ref name=CanBars_1/> From within a sample of 876 disk galaxies identified by visual classification in Galaxy Zoo 4, 123 barred galaxies are examined. It is found that the bar fraction across the redshift range 0.5 < z < 2 does not significantly evolve.<ref name=CanBars_1/>
== Galaxy mergers and interactions == [[File:NGC4676.jpg|thumb| right| A [[Hubble Space Telescope|HST]] image of the '[[Mice Galaxies]]' which are in the process of merging.]] Galaxy Zoo Mergers was a Galaxy Zoo project started in November 2009 and retired in June 2012. There have also been a number of studies on galaxy mergers, among which was a survey of ≈3000, which presented "the largest, most homogeneous catalogue of merging galaxies in the nearby universe".<ref name=DargMerg1>{{cite journal| authors=D.W.Darg, S.Kaviraj, C.J.Lintott, K.Schawinski| display-authors=etal| date=2010| title=Galaxy Zoo: the fraction of merging galaxies in the SDSS and their morphologies| journal=MNRAS| volume=441| issue=2| bibcode=2010MNRAS.401.1043D| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.15686.x| arxiv=0903.4937| pages=1043–1056}}</ref><ref name=DargMerg2>{{cite journal| author=D.W.Darg, S.Kaviraj, C.J.Lintott, K. Schawinski| display-authors=etal| date=2010| title=Galaxy Zoo: the properties of merging galaxies in the nearby Universe - local environments, colours, masses, star formation rates and AGN activity| journal=MNRAS| volume=410| issue=3| bibcode=2010MNRAS.401.1552D| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.15786.x| arxiv=0903.5057| pages=1552–1563}}</ref> This catalogue was spread over two papers and was a result of volunteers selecting likely candidates from Galaxy Zoo 1 and posting them on the Galaxy Zoo forum. Other papers that have used Galaxy Zoo data resulted in observations that include those taken by the [[Chandra X-ray Observatory]].<ref name=Shabala_Dust_Mergers/><ref name=Teng_1>{{cite journal| author=S.H. Teng, K.Schawinski, C. Megan Urry, D.W. Darg, S. Kaviraj, Kyuseok Oh, E.W. Bonning, C.N. Cardamone, W.C. Keel, C.J. Lintott, B.D. Simmons, E. Treister| date=2012| title=Chandra Observations of Galaxy Zoo Mergers: Frequency of Binary Active Nuclei in Massive Mergers| journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]]| volume=753| issue=2| arxiv=1206.1266| bibcode=2012ApJ...753..165T| doi=10.1088/0004-637X/753/2/165| pages=165}}</ref><ref name=Carpineti_1>{{ cite journal|author1=A. Carpineti |author2=S. Kaviraj |author3=D. Darg |author4=C. Lintott |author5=K. Schawinski |author6=S. Shabala | date=2012| title=Spheroidal post-mergers in the local Universe| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=420| issue=3| arxiv=1111.5008| bibcode=2012MNRAS.420.2139C| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20179.x | pages=2139–2146}}</ref><ref name=Darg_3>{{ cite journal|author1=D.W. Darg |author2=S. Kaviraj |author3=C.J. Lintott |author4=K. Schawinski |author5=J. Silk |author6=S. Lynn |author7=S. Bamford |author8=R.C. Nichol | date=2011| title=Galaxy Zoo: multimergers and the Millennium Simulation| journal=[[MNRAS]]| volume=416| issue=3| arxiv=1012.4214| bibcode=2011MNRAS.416.1745D| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18964.x | pages=1745–1755}}</ref>
== Getting it Right or Being Top Rank ==
A 2018 study published in the online journal ''Citizen Science: Theory and Practice'' compares two [[citizen science]] projects, Foldit and GZ, to explore the difference between projects that do or don't use gaming to obtain data.<ref name=GIR> {{cite journal | last1 = Ponti | first1 = Marisa | last2 = Hillman | first2 = Thomas | last3 = Kullenberg | first3 = Christopher | last4 = Kasperowski | first4 = Dick | date = 23 January 2018 | title = Getting it Right or Being Top Rank: Games in Citizen Science | journal = Citizen Science: Theory and Practice | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–12 | doi = 10.5334/cstp.101 }} </ref> Over a one-year period, the authors conducted a virtual ethnographic study of the public forums of both projects by using [[web scraping]] techniques. The abstract ends: "We conclude that ideals of science embraced by citizen scientists appear to influence the reasons why they participate, either emphasizing equality, like in Galazy Zoo, or meritocracy, like in Foldit."<ref name=GIR/>{{rp|1}}
==Examples== Examples of crowdsourced astronomy projects include: * Galaxy Zoo: morphologies derived from visual inspection of galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Lintott |first=Chris J. |author-link=Chris Lintott |last2=Schawinski |first2=Kevin |author-link2=Kevin Schawinski |last3=Slosar |first3=Anže |last4=Land |first4=Kate |last5=Bamford |first5=Steven |last6=Thomas |first6=Daniel |last7=Raddick |first7=M. Jordan |last8=Nichol |first8=Robert C. |last9=Szalay |first9=Alex |author-link9=Alex Szalay |date=9 September 2008 |orig-year=29 Apr 2008 |title=Galaxy Zoo: morphologies derived from visual inspection of galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=389 |issue=3 |pages=1179–1189 |arxiv=0804.4483 |bibcode=2008MNRAS.389.1179L |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.13689.x |first10=Dan |last10=Andreescu |first11=Phil |last11=Murray |first12=Jan |last12=van den Berg}}</ref> * Galaxy Zoo 1: data release of morphological classifications for nearly 900,000 galaxies.<ref name="GZ_1"/> * Galaxy Zoo 2: detailed morphological classifications for 304,122 galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.<ref name="GZ_2"/> * Galaxy Zoo: the dependence of morphology and colour on environment.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bamford |first=Steven P. |last2=Nichol |first2=Robert C. |last3=Baldry |first3=Ivan K. |last4=Land |first4=Kate |last5=Lintott |first5=Chris J. |author-link5=Chris Lintott |last6=Schawinski |first6=Kevin |author-link6=Kevin Schawinski |last7=Slosar |first7=Anže |last8=Szalay |first8=Alexander S. |last9=Thomas |first9=Daniel |date=26 February 2009 |orig-year=14 Nov 2008 |title=Galaxy Zoo: the dependence of morphology and colour on environment |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=393 |issue=4 |pages=1324–1352 |arxiv=0805.2612 |bibcode=2009MNRAS.393.1324B |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.14252.x |first10=Mehri |last10=Torki |first11=Dan |last11=Andreescu |first12=Edward M. |last12=Edmondson |first13=Christopher J. |last13=Miller |first14=Phil |last14=Murray |first15=M. Jordan |last15=Raddick |first16=Jan |last16=Vandenberg}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Das Adlige Kanonissenstift St. Cyriakus zu Geseke.jpg|alt=|thumb| ''Neue Folge 14'']] [[File:Germania Sacra Das Zisterzienserinnen-, später Benedikterkloster St. Aegidii zu Münster.jpg|alt=|thumb| ''Dritte Folge 1'']]
'''Germania Sacra''' ([[Latin]] for "Sacred/Holy Germania/Germany") is a long-term research project into German [[History of the Roman Catholic Church|church history]] from its beginnings through [[the Reformation]] in the 16th century to the period of [[secularisation]] in the early 19th century.
== History and Structure == The first attempt to collect and publish the history of the German dioceses in reference books was made by [[Martin Gerbert]], the prince-abbot of the monastery [[Sankt Blasien|St. Blasien]] in the late 18<sup>th</sup> century, but his works were never completed.
Following into Gerberts footsteps, [[Paul Fridolin Kehr]] established a new ''Germania Sacra'' under the patronage of the ''[[Kaiser Wilhelm Society|Kaiser-Wilhelm-Society]]'' at the ''Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institute of German History'' in [[Berlin]] in 1917. He tried to connect the nationwide research projects and combine them under ''Germania Sacra'' to create an archival collection of [[Monastery|monasteries]], [[Convent|convents]], [[Cathedral chapter|cathedral chapters]] and religious dignitaries. After multiple financial problems, the first book was published on 11<sup>th</sup> of June in 1929. It is part of the ''“Alte Folge”'', which comprises seven volumes published between 1929 and 1972.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://adw-goe.de/en/research/research-projects-within-the-academies-programme/germania-sacra/publications/|title=Germania Sacra Publications|last=|first=|date=2018-06-27|website=Göttingen Academy of Sciences and Humanities; Germania Sacra|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
After the 2<sup>nd</sup> World War and the death of Kehr, the ''Kaiser-Wilhelm-Society'' wasn’t interested in supporting the institute any longer and the newly founded ''[[Max Planck Society|Max-Planck-Society]]'' took over the patronage of the institute and its project. Hermann Heimpel, the first head of the ''Max-Planck-Institute of History'' in [[Göttingen]], continued work on the ''Germania Sacra'' in 1956, cooperating with an academic director, who coordinated the work of external researchers. While the last books of the ''Alte Folge'' were published between 1966 and 1972, the researchers under Heimpel began writing and publishing the ''Neue Folge'', which were released between 1962 and 2007 in 50 volumes.<ref name=":0" /> In 2007, the ''Max-Planck-Institute of History'' in Göttingen was rededicated and the work on the ''Germania Sacra'' was continued by the''Academy of Sciences and Humanities'' under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Hedwig Röckelein in Göttingen in 2008. <ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://adw-goe.de/en/research/research-projects-within-the-academies-programme/germania-sacra/|title=Germania Sacra|last=|first=|date=2018-06-27|website=Göttingen Academy of Sciences and Humanities; Germania Sacra|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>The volumes of the ''Germania Sacra'' published after 2008 belong to the ''Dritte Folge'' and currently comprise 14 volumes (as of: June 2018).<ref name=":0" />
In 2015 the first supplementary volume was published, which contains edited preparation work to the main works of ''Germania Sacra''. <ref name=":1" />
== Objectives and methods == The main objective of ''Germania Sacra'' is a statistical description of the ecclesiastical institutions which existed between the ''[[Holy Roman Empire]]'' and the period of secularisation in the early 19<sup>th</sup> century. In achieving that objective, the entirety of sources and secondary literature concerning Medieval and Early Modern ecclesiastical institutions is to be portrayed. These institutions include the [[Diocese|dioceses]] (with focus on the bishops), the [[Cathedral chapter|cathedral chapters]] and the monasteries and convents up to and including their end during the reformation or the secularisation. At the beginning, the collection and the editing of the historical sources was mainly conducted by archivists at the request of Paul Kehr. In the present, the work on ''Germania Sacra'' is divided between historical research and the editorial department. The research is conducted by archivists, historians, members of ecclesiastical orders, theologians etc.
''Germania Sacras'' publications are divided into the ''Alte Folge'', the ''Neue Folge,'' the ''Dritte Folge,'' the ''Studien zur Germania Sacra'' and the ''Supplementbände zur Germania Sacra''.<ref name=":0" />
In addition to the volumes of ''Germania Sacra,'' the project provides two databases. A comprehensive inventory of medieval and early modern clerics <ref>http://personendatenbank.germania-sacra.de</ref> and the "Database of monasteries, convents and collegiate churches of the Old Empire "<ref>http://klosterdatenbank.germania-sacra.de</ref>
== Publications and digital editions ==
=== ''Alte Folge'' === {| class="wikitable" !No. !Title !Author !Year of Publication !Online |- | data-sort-value="AF 1" | AF Abt 1 | ''Das [[Bishopric of Brandenburg|Bistum Brandenburg]] 1 (Germania Sacra A. F. Abt. 1: Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz Magdeburg)'' | [[Gustav Abb]], Gottfried Wentz | 1929 | [http://hdl.handle.net/11858/00-001S-0000-0022-D47D-E Digitalisat] |- | data-sort-value="AF 1" | AF Abt 1 | ''Das Bistum Brandenburg 2 (Germania Sacra A. F. Abt. 1: Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz Magdeburg)'' | Fritz Bünger, Gottfried Wentz | 1941 | [http://hdl.handle.net/11858/00-001S-0000-0022-D474-F Digitalisat] |- | data-sort-value="AF 1" | AF Abt 1 | ''Das [[Bishopric of Havelberg|Bistum Havelberg]] (Germania Sacra A. F. Abt. 1: Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz [[Magdeburg]])'' | Gottfried Wentz | 1933 | [http://hdl.handle.net/11858/00-001S-0000-0022-D478-7 Digitalisat] |- | data-sort-value="AF 1" | AF Abt 1 | ''Das [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Magdeburg|Erzbistum Magdeburg]] 1,1: Das Domstift St. Moritz in Magdeburg (Germania Sacra A. F. Abt. 1: Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz Magdeburg)'' | Gottfried Wentz, [[Berent Schwineköper]] | 1972 | [http://hdl.handle.net/11858/00-001S-0000-0022-D475-D Digitalisat] |- | data-sort-value="AF 1" | AF Abt 1 | ''Das Erzbistum Magdeburg 1,2: Die Kollegiatstifte St. Sebastian, St. Nicolai, St. Peter und Paul und St. Gangolf in Magdeburg (Germania Sacra A. F. Abt. 1: Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz Magdeburg)'' | Gottfried Wentz, [[Berent Schwineköper]] | 1972 | [http://hdl.handle.net/11858/00-001S-0000-0022-D479-5 Digitalisat] |- | data-sort-value="AF 2" | AF Abt 2 | ''Das [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bamberg|Bistum Bamberg]] 1 (Germania Sacra A. F. Abt. 2: Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz Mainz)'' | Erich von Guttenberg | 1937 | |- | data-sort-value="AF 2" | AF Abt 2 | ''Das Bistum Bamberg 2: Die Pfarreiorganisation (Germania Sacra A. F. Abt. 2: Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz Mainz)'' | Erich von Guttenberg, Alfred Wendehorst | 1966 | |- | data-sort-value="AF 3" | AF Abt 3 | ''Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz Köln: Archidiakonat von Xanten (Germania Sacra A. F. Abt. 3: Die Bistümer der Kirchenprovinz Köln)'' | Wilhelm Classen | 1938 | [http://hdl.handle.net/11858/00-001S-0000-0022-D47C-0 Digitalisat] |- |} ===''Neue Folge''===

== Literature== * Georg Pfeilschifter: ''Die St. Blasianische Germania Sacra''. ''Ein Beitrag zur Historiographie des 18. Jahrhunderts''. Kempten, 1921. * Irene Crusius: ''Beiträge zu Geschichte und Struktur der mittelalterlichen Germania sacra.'' Göttingen, 1989. * Irene Crusius: ''Die Germania Sacra. Stand und Perspektiven eines langfristigen Forschungsprojekts''. In: ''Deutsches Archiv für Erforschung des Mittelalters.'' Vol. 52, 1996, pp. 629–642. * Wolfgang Müller (Bearb.): ''Briefe und Akten des Fürstabtes Martin Gerbert.'' 2 volumes, 1962. *Sven Kriese: Die Germania Sacra in der Weimarer Republik und im Nationalsozialismus. In: Hedwig Röckelein (ed.), 100 Jahre Germania Sacra. Kirchengeschichte Schreiben vom 16. bis zum 21. Jahrhundert (Studien zur Germania Sacra. Neue Folge 8). Berlin/Boston 2018 (In Press), pp.87-118.
